greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = pi(n) - pi(floor(n/2)), where pi is A000720.
comment: Also, the number of unitary prime divisors of n!. A prime divisor of n is unitary iff its exponent is 1 in the prime power factorization of n. In general, gcd(p, n/p) = 1 or p. Here we count the cases when gcd(p, n/p) = 1.
A unitary prime divisor of n! is >= n/2, hence their number is pi(n) - pi(n/2). - _Peter Luschny_, Mar 13 2011
See also the references and links mentioned in A143227. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Aug 03 2008
Lev Schnirelmann proved that for every n, a(n) > (1/log_2(n))*(n/3 - 4*sqrt(n)) - 1 - (3/2)*log_2(n). - _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Nov 03 2017
link: Daniel Forgues, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..100000
formula: a(n) = A000720(n) - A056172(n). - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Apr 09 2017
example: 10! = 2^8 * 3^2 * 5^2 * 7. The only unitary prime divisor is 7, so a(10)=1.
mathematica: s=0; Table[If[PrimeQ[k], s++]; If[PrimeQ[k/2], s--]; s, {k,100}]
program: [primepi(n) - primepi(n//2) for n in range(1,151)] # _Indranil Ghosh_, Mar 22 2017
xref: Cf. A080359, A080360. - _Robert G. Wilson v_, Mar 20 2017
results.author: _Labos Elemer_, Jul 27 2000
ext: Definition simplified by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Sep 01 2015
